Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Proteasomal Removal of Selenoproteins in Plants

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals (including humans) require selenium to make the amino acid selenocysteine, which is used in the synthesis of essential selenoproteins. In contrast, plants do not require selenium or make specific selenoproteins. Nonetheless, plants can accumulate selenium and play a vital role in providing most of the dietary selenium consumed by humans. However, an excess of selenium leads to toxicity in plants when selenocysteine is incorporated into proteins. Selenoproteins in plants are likely misfolded, and are therefore removed by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. The goal of this project is to understand the role of the proteasome and glutathione in removing selenoproteins and alleviating their toxicity in plants.

Broader Impacts. The project will directly allow the training of ten undergraduate students, including students with disabilities, at Coastal Carolina University. This project will also facilitate the development of an upper-level laboratory-based class "Plant Adaptations to Stress" which will integrate this research with teaching.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most humans meet their dietary requirement of selenium via the consumption of plants.  However, at high levels, selenium can be toxic to plants.  The goal of this project was to explore the modes of selenium toxicity in plants.  The scientific outcome of this project includes the discovery that proteasomes can alleviate selenium toxicity in canola and algae by removing malformed selenoproteins containing a cysteine to selenocysteine substitution. Proteasome are well studied in animals, including humans, where they play a role in cellular homeostasis by removing misfolded proteins.  In addition, we learned that selenium toxicity causes mitochondrial oxidative stress, which requires reprogramming of cellular activities to adaquetly respond to this stress; this response includes altered metabolite profile, increased respiration, and increased antioxidant metabolism.  Therefore, selenium stress in plants stems from two different modes of toxicity.  Additionally, the project facilitated a collaborative project in Turkey that studied whether or not rare nickel-hyperaccumulating have increased proteasome activity.

 

The project trained 6 undergraduate students, and enabled a collaboration with the Accessibility Office that allowed the recruitment and training of a student with a physical disability.  Furthermore, the project facilitated the purchase of a spectrofluorometer that is used by various faculty members in my department. This scientific instrument was used to redesign a labortory exercise in a cell biology class, which benefited numerous students in the Biology and Biochemistry Department.
